sub_subject.name: Grammar, Mechanics & Linguistics
sub_subject.description: 13-year academic progression (K-12) for Grammar, Mechanics & Linguistics (Language Arts & Humanities)

objectives.objective_text: Identify rhyming sounds.
Identify dipthongs and blends.

objectives.topic_name: Parts of Speech and Word Functions
objectives.objective_text: Identify simple pronouns (I, you, he, she, it, we, they).
Identify a short sentence.
Identify FANBOYS conjunctions.
Identify the direct object (vertical line that doesn't cross).
Identify that words change over time.
Name "Old English" as the language of Beowulf.
Identify the Great Vowel Shift.
Identify a root word inside a bigger word.
Identify bound vs. free morphemes.
Identify happy words vs. sad words.
Name opposites (antonyms).
Identify sarcasm or implied meaning.

objectives.topic_name: Parts of Speech and Word Functions
objectives.objective_text: Identify adjectives as words that describe things.

objectives.topic_name: Parts of Speech and Word Functions
objectives.objective_text: Identify adverbs as words that describe actions (often ending in -ly).

objectives.topic_name: Parts of Speech and Word Functions
objectives.objective_text: Identify that the same word can do different jobs (e.g., 'I *run*' vs. 'A long *run*').

objectives.topic_name: Parts of Speech and Word Functions
objectives.objective_text: Identify when a noun is acting like an adjective (e.g., 'chicken' soup).

objectives.topic_name: Parts of Speech and Word Functions
objectives.objective_text: Identify nouns as names for a person, place, thing, or idea.

objectives.topic_name: Parts of Speech and Word Functions
objectives.objective_text: Identify the function of a noun in a sentence (Subject or Object).

objectives.topic_name: Parts of Speech and Word Functions
objectives.objective_text: Identify position words (in, on, under, beside).

objectives.topic_name: Parts of Speech and Word Functions
objectives.objective_text: Identify prepositional phrases in a sentence.

objectives.topic_name: Parts of Speech and Word Functions
objectives.objective_text: Identify verbs as 'doing' words or 'being' words.

objectives.topic_name: Parts of Speech and Word Functions
objectives.objective_text: Identify helping verbs (is, am, are, was, were).

objectives.topic_name: Parts of Speech and Word Functions
objectives.objective_text: Identify the main verb phrase in a sentence.
Identify a complete thought.
Name the "Subject" and the "Action".
Identify subordinate conjunctions (because, if, when).
Identify words that tell "where" (in the box).
Name a group of words acting together.
Identify Participial Phrases (-ing words describing).
Identify "He runs" vs. "They run".
Identify collective nouns (team, family) as singular.
Identify big letters at the start of a sentence.
Name "I" as always big.
Identify capitalization in titles of works.
Identify a pause in a sentence.
Identify the Oxford Comma debate.
Identify a period, question mark, and exclamation point.
Identify split quotations.
Identify "a" vs "an".
Identify misplaced modifiers.
Identify action words ending in -ing.
Name "To run" as a verb form.
Identify a predicate nominative vs. predicate adjective.
Identify sentences that sound the same.
Identify loose vs. periodic sentences.
Recall that letters represent sounds.
Observe how mouth shape changes sound.
Recall that we can make long sentences.
Observe punctuation rules for joining.
Recall that describing words hang down.
Analyze the International Phonetic Alphabet (IPA) chart (intro).
Recall that English borrowed words from French and Latin.
Observe how Shakespeareâ€™s words look different from ours.
Recall that "un-" means not.
Observe how endings change part of speech (quick -> quickly).
Recall that "bank" can mean money place or river side.
Observe politeness words ("Please").

objectives.topic_name: Parts of Speech and Word Functions
objectives.objective_text: Recognize that words have jobs in a sentence.

objectives.topic_name: Parts of Speech and Word Functions
objectives.objective_text: Observe that word order matters.

objectives.topic_name: Parts of Speech and Word Functions
objectives.objective_text: Recognize that some words connect ideas.
Recall that a sentence needs a capital and a period.
Observe sentences joined by "and".
Recall that phrases don't have a subject doing a verb.
Observe extra details in a sentence.
Recall that "is" and "are" change based on who it is.
Observe plurals ending in 's' often don't have 's' on the verb.
Recall that names of people and places get big letters.
Observe titles on books.
Recall commas in dates and cities.
Observe commas after "Yes" or "No".
Recall that "talking marks" hug the words spoken.
Observe punctuation inside the quotes.
Recall double negatives are a no-no.
Observe "good" vs "well".
Recall that some verb-looking words act like nouns.
Observe complex sentences.
Recall that variety is interesting.
Observe how Yoda talks (weird syntax).
Clap syllables in a name.
Summarize the difference between vowels and consonants.
Explain phonemes (smallest unit of sound).
Explain dialect variations in pronunciation.
Defend the importance of clear articulation.

objectives.topic_name: Parts of Speech and Word Functions
objectives.objective_text: Change verbs to show past, present, and future (simple tenses).
Combine two sentences with "and".
Summarize Simple (one idea) vs. Compound (two equal ideas).
Explain Complex sentences (one strong, one weak part).
Explain run-on sentences and splices.
Defend the need for variety to keep reader interest.
Summarize the basic rule of agreement.
Draw a horizontal line.
Separate the Who (Subject) and Did What (Verb) with a vertical line.
Diagram "Dogs bark."
Summarize the baseline of a diagram.
Explain where adjectives and adverbs go (slanted lines under).
Diagram "The big red dog runs fast."
Explain the understood "You" in commands.
Defend the discipline of sentence analysis.
Explain the impact of the Norman Conquest (1066) on vocabulary.
Summarize the three main periods: Old, Middle, and Modern English.
Explain the standardization of spelling (dictionaries).
Defend the beauty of language evolution.
Add "s" to make plural or "ed" for past.
Summarize the meaning of common Latin roots (e.g., struct, port).
Explain the difference between a base word and a root.
Break a complex word into morphemes.
Explain the concept of agglutination (intro).
Defend the logic of English spelling based on morphology.
Summarize synonyms (words that mean the same).
Explain idiom phrases ("It's raining cats and dogs").
Explain ambiguity.
Defend the power of words to bless or curse (Proverbs 18:21).

objectives.topic_name: Parts of Speech and Word Functions
objectives.objective_text: Use describing words to make sentences more interesting.

objectives.topic_name: Parts of Speech and Word Functions
objectives.objective_text: Sort words into 'Describing a Thing' vs. 'Describing an Action'.

objectives.topic_name: Parts of Speech and Word Functions
objectives.objective_text: Categorize adjectives by what they tell (Which one? What kind? How many?).

objectives.topic_name: Parts of Speech and Word Functions
objectives.objective_text: Form comparative (-er) and superlative (-est) adjectives correctly.

objectives.topic_name: Parts of Speech and Word Functions
objectives.objective_text: Use adverbs to modify verbs, adjectives, and other adverbs.

objectives.topic_name: Parts of Speech and Word Functions
objectives.objective_text: Distinguish between 'Good' (adjective) and 'Well' (adverb).

objectives.topic_name: Parts of Speech and Word Functions
objectives.objective_text: Explain the order of adjectives (Quantity, Quality, Size, Age, Shape, Color, Origin, Material).

objectives.topic_name: Parts of Speech and Word Functions
objectives.objective_text: Defend the use of a dangling modifier (or correct it).

objectives.topic_name: Parts of Speech and Word Functions
objectives.objective_text: Sort words into 'Nouns' and 'Verbs' based on how they are used.

objectives.topic_name: Parts of Speech and Word Functions
objectives.objective_text: Explain how a word like 'paint' can be a noun or a verb.

objectives.topic_name: Parts of Speech and Word Functions
objectives.objective_text: Explain why dictionaries list multiple parts of speech for one word.

objectives.topic_name: Parts of Speech and Word Functions
objectives.objective_text: Defend the flexibility of English morphology.

objectives.topic_name: Parts of Speech and Word Functions
objectives.objective_text: Distinguish between common (city) and proper (London) nouns.

objectives.topic_name: Parts of Speech and Word Functions
objectives.objective_text: Form plural nouns by adding -s or -es.

objectives.topic_name: Parts of Speech and Word Functions
objectives.objective_text: Capitalize proper nouns in own writing.

objectives.topic_name: Parts of Speech and Word Functions
objectives.objective_text: Categorize nouns as abstract (courage), concrete (rock), or collective (herd).

objectives.topic_name: Parts of Speech and Word Functions
objectives.objective_text: Form possessive nouns correctly (singular and plural).

objectives.topic_name: Parts of Speech and Word Functions
objectives.objective_text: Use appositives to rename nouns.

objectives.topic_name: Parts of Speech and Word Functions
objectives.objective_text: Explain the function of a noun clause.

objectives.topic_name: Parts of Speech and Word Functions
objectives.objective_text: Defend the capitalization of theological terms based on style guides.

objectives.topic_name: Parts of Speech and Word Functions
objectives.objective_text: Use 'and', 'but', and 'or' to join words.

objectives.topic_name: Parts of Speech and Word Functions
objectives.objective_text: Follow instructions with positional words.

objectives.topic_name: Parts of Speech and Word Functions
objectives.objective_text: Use subordinating conjunctions (because, since, if) to make complex sentences.

objectives.topic_name: Parts of Speech and Word Functions
objectives.objective_text: Explain the object of a preposition.

objectives.topic_name: Parts of Speech and Word Functions
objectives.objective_text: Explain how prepositions show relationships of time and space.

objectives.topic_name: Parts of Speech and Word Functions
objectives.objective_text: Defend the use of polysyndeton or asyndeton in rhetoric.

objectives.topic_name: Parts of Speech and Word Functions
objectives.objective_text: Replace a name with the correct pronoun.

objectives.topic_name: Parts of Speech and Word Functions
objectives.objective_text: Use 'I' correctly when talking about self.

objectives.topic_name: Parts of Speech and Word Functions
objectives.objective_text: Match pronouns to the person they are talking about.

objectives.topic_name: Parts of Speech and Word Functions
objectives.objective_text: Categorize pronouns by type (Personal, Possessive, Reflexive).

objectives.topic_name: Parts of Speech and Word Functions
objectives.objective_text: Ensure pronouns agree with their antecedents in number and gender.

objectives.topic_name: Parts of Speech and Word Functions
objectives.objective_text: Use relative pronouns (who, which, that) to start clauses.

objectives.topic_name: Parts of Speech and Word Functions
objectives.objective_text: Distinguish between subject pronouns (I) and object pronouns (me).

objectives.topic_name: Parts of Speech and Word Functions
objectives.objective_text: Explain the function of indefinite pronouns and verb agreement.

objectives.topic_name: Parts of Speech and Word Functions
objectives.objective_text: Defend the grammatical logic of pronoun case in elliptical clauses (e.g., 'taller than I').

objectives.topic_name: Parts of Speech and Word Functions
objectives.objective_text: Match verbs to the subject (He runs, They run).

objectives.topic_name: Parts of Speech and Word Functions
objectives.objective_text: Categorize verbs as Action, Linking, or Helping.

objectives.topic_name: Parts of Speech and Word Functions
objectives.objective_text: Form perfect tenses (have/had + participle) correctly.

objectives.topic_name: Parts of Speech and Word Functions
objectives.objective_text: Use irregular verbs correctly in the past tense.

objectives.topic_name: Parts of Speech and Word Functions
objectives.objective_text: Explain how modal verbs (might, should, must) change meaning.

objectives.topic_name: Parts of Speech and Word Functions
objectives.objective_text: Defend the use of the Subjunctive Mood for hypothetical situations.
Summarize an Independent Clause (can stand alone).
Explain a Dependent Clause (needs a helper).
Explain restrictive vs. non-restrictive clauses (comma usage).
Defend the use of complex syntax for complex thoughts.
Summarize Prepositional Phrases (starts with prep, ends with noun).
Explain Appositives (renaming the noun).
Use an Infinitive Phrase (to run) as a noun.
Explain Absolute Phrases.
Defend the stylistic choice of sentence fragments (rarely).
Match singular nouns to singular verbs.
Explain compound subjects joined by "and" (usually plural).
Handle "or" situations (match the closer subject).
Explain agreement with amounts ($10 is enough).
Defend the clarity that agreement provides.
Summarize capitalizing days, months, and holidays.
Explain proper nouns vs. common nouns.
Capitalize titles of people (Dr., Mrs., President) correctly.
Explain brand names vs. generic products.
Defend the conventions of standard English.
Use commas in a list (apples, bananas, and pears).
Summarize using a comma with a conjunction to join sentences.
Explain using a semicolon to join related sentences.
Use commas to set off introductory phrases.
Explain colon usage for lists or emphasis.
Defend the rules of punctuation as aids to breathing and logic.
Match the mark to the sentence type.
Summarize the four sentence types (Declarative, Interrogative, etc.).
Explain how to punctuate dialogue.
Use single quotes for quotes inside quotes.
Explain the ellipsis (...) for omitted words.
Defend the integrity of quoting sources accurately.
Use "I" instead of "Me" in the subject.
Summarize homophone errors (to/two/too).
Explain "lie" vs "lay".
Distinguish "fewer" (countable) vs "less" (uncountable).
Explain "who" vs "whom".
Defend the standard of excellence in communication.
Summarize Gerunds (nouns), Participles (adjectives), Infinitives (nouns/adj/adv).
Explain how to diagram a prepositional phrase on a slant line.
Diagram a direct and indirect object.
Explain the objective complement.
Defend the structure of language as a reflection of logical order.
Make a sentence long or short.
Summarize S-V-O (Subject-Verb-Object) order.
Explain Inverted Syntax for effect ("Into the room walked the king").
Explain balanced sentences.
Defend the choice of syntax to control pacing.
Compare voiced and unvoiced sounds (b vs. p).
Interpret stress patterns in multi-syllabic words.
Connect intonation to meaning (question vs. statement).
Analyze sentence variety in a paragraph.
Interpret the relationship between clauses in a complex sentence.
Connect sentence structure to pacing.
Analyze the placement of compound subjects and verbs (rocket ship shape).
Interpret the visual representation of sentence logic.
Connect parts of speech to their diagram position.
Connect Greek roots to scientific vocabulary.
Analyze the influence of the King James Bible on English idioms.
Interpret the etymology of common words.
Connect global trade to loanwords (e.g., pajama, ketchup).
Analyze how prefixes alter meaning (negation, direction, time).
Interpret derivational vs. inflectional suffixes.
Compare literal meaning vs. figurative meaning.
Analyze connotation vs. denotation.
Interpret speech acts (requests, commands, promises).
Connect context to word meaning (Polysemy).

objectives.objective_text: Analyze the placement of modifiers to avoid confusion.

objectives.objective_text: Interpret the use of intensifiers (very, really, quite).

objectives.objective_text: Connect predicate adjectives to linking verbs.

objectives.objective_text: Compare the form of a word with its function.

objectives.objective_text: Apply knowledge of parts of speech to fix sentences.

objectives.objective_text: Interpret the function of a word based on its suffix.

objectives.objective_text: Connect sentence diagramming to determining function.

objectives.topic_name: Parts of Speech and Word Functions
objectives.objective_text: Analyze the role of nominalization (turning verbs/adjectives into nouns).

objectives.objective_text: Interpret the difference between count and non-count nouns.

objectives.topic_name: Parts of Speech and Word Functions
objectives.objective_text: Connect noun usage to subject-verb agreement in complex sentences.

objectives.topic_name: Parts of Speech and Word Functions
objectives.objective_text: Connect ideas logically using transition words.

objectives.objective_text: Analyze the function of correlative conjunctions (either/or, neither/nor).

objectives.objective_text: Interpret the difference between a preposition and an adverb.

objectives.topic_name: Parts of Speech and Word Functions
objectives.objective_text: Connect the use of conjunctions to sentence flow.

objectives.topic_name: Parts of Speech and Word Functions
objectives.objective_text: Analyze the case of pronouns (Nominative, Objective, Possessive).

objectives.objective_text: Interpret the correct usage of 'Who' vs. 'Whom'.

objectives.topic_name: Parts of Speech and Word Functions
objectives.objective_text: Connect demonstrative pronouns to the pointing function.

objectives.objective_text: Interpret the difference between Active and Passive voice.

objectives.objective_text: Connect verb aspect (Progressive, Perfect) to the timing of an action.
Compare a phrase (no verb) with a clause (has verb).
Analyze Relative Clauses (starting with who/which/that).
Interpret Noun Clauses acting as subjects or objects.
Connect clause variety to writing flow.
Analyze the function of a Gerund Phrase (acting as a noun).
Interpret how phrases modify other words.
Connect phrase placement to clarity (avoiding dangling modifiers).
Analyze agreement with indefinite pronouns (everyone, somebody).
Interpret intervening phrases ("The box of apples is heavy").
Connect "There is/There are" to the subject that follows.
Analyze the capitalization of Deity pronouns (He/Him for God).
Interpret regional capitalizations (North vs. north).
Connect capitalization to specific historical events.
Analyze non-essential clauses (set off by commas).
Interpret the semicolon as a "soft period".
Connect commas to direct address ("John, come here").
Analyze the placement of periods/commas inside quotes (US standard).
Interpret the use of block quotes for long passages.
Connect exclamation points to emotion (use sparingly).
Analyze parallel structure in lists.
Interpret passive voice vs. active voice.
Connect clarity to proper usage.
Analyze the diagramming of noun clauses on stilts.
Interpret the diagramming of compound sentences (dotted line connection).
Connect syntax to logical analysis of thought.
Compare active syntax with passive syntax.
Analyze the rhetorical effect of sentence length.
Interpret parallelism in famous speeches.
Connect syntax to authorial voice.
Evaluate the difficulty of English phonology for learners.
Evaluate the impact of short, choppy sentences vs. flowing ones.
Evaluate why we diagram (to see how words work together).
Construct a phonetic transcription of a simple sentence.
Evaluate the fluidity of language ("correctness" vs. usage).
Evaluate the clarity of neologisms.
Evaluate how tone changes meaning.

objectives.objective_text: Evaluate the overuse of adverbs (show, don't tell).

objectives.objective_text: Evaluate the grammatical correctness of functional shifts.

Construct a persuasive paragraph using all four types.

objectives.objective_text: Construct sentences with nuanced modification.

objectives.objective_text: Synthesize adjectival clauses for precise description.

objectives.objective_text: Construct sentences where words shift function for rhetorical effect (anthimeria).

objectives.objective_text: Synthesize form and function in linguistic analysis.

objectives.objective_text: Construct sentences using sophisticated nominal structures.

objectives.objective_text: Synthesize noun functions within gerund phrases.

objectives.objective_text: Construct complex sentences maintaining consistent verb tense.
